meanings.definition: A thin piece of wood that is used for various purposes.
meanings.sent1: I found a stick on the ground and used it as a tool.
meanings.sent2: The boy picked up a stick to play fetch with his dog.
meanings.sent3: The stick rolled down the hill and into the pond.
meanings.sent4: Her words were like a sharp stick poking at his emotions.
meanings.sent5: The stick cracked loudly as he stepped on it in the forest.

meanings.definition: To adhere or cling to something.
meanings.sent1: The tape will stick to the paper if you press it down firmly.
meanings.sent2: The wet shirt started to stick to his skin in the hot sun.
meanings.sent3: The sticker refused to stick to the bumpy surface of the notebook.
meanings.sent4: Her words of encouragement seemed to stick in his mind for days.
meanings.sent5: The memory of that day would stick with her forever.

meanings.definition: To insert or thrust something into something else.
meanings.sent1: He tried to stick the key into the lock, but it wouldn't turn.
meanings.sent2: The chef had to stick toothpicks into the sliders to hold them together.
meanings.sent3: She decided to stick a flower into her hair for a pop of color.
meanings.sent4: The detective tried to stick the pieces of the case together to solve it.
meanings.sent5: The artist would stick pieces of fabric onto the canvas for texture.

meanings.definition: To remain in a place or position.
meanings.sent1: Please stick around after the meeting for a quick chat.
meanings.sent2: The cat would stick to the sunny spot on the carpet all day.
meanings.sent3: The idea seemed to stick in his mind, growing stronger with each passing day.
meanings.sent4: Her smile would stick in his memory long after she had left.
meanings.sent5: The scent of fresh bread would stick in the air of the bakery.
